pros: Employees who really cared for patients

Facility was horribly outdated and filthy-when given an office I had to take a mop and bucket of water and wipe the walls down.

pros:
This is more than just another job or random place to work. The opportunities are endless. There's always room to grow here, at Metrocare Services. 
Being a mental health professional has also become a lifestyle-for me. 
When I walk into my office; I'm there to help, change minds and change lives. 
When I walk out, I feel rewarded.
If you want to join an awesome team-a company, like family; come join us!
You'll make a positive impact, while contributing to both your and our community. 
You will be a service. You'll learn. You'll increase. You'll invest in self; while making great success, within your own career.
cons: None comes to mind, at this time.

job_title: Certified Peer Specialist Supervisor in Dallas, TX
pros: Metrocare cares deeply about its clients providing case management, peer support, medication management, wrap-around services for individuals, and curriculums that will assist clients with their recovery. Metrocare works with adults and youth providing full support. Metrocare is on the cutting edge as a Certified Trauma-Informed organization ensuring that clients' needs are met. The company offers many perks for the employees such as counseling, floating holidays, support from the management team, great insurance benefits, recognition of staff's hard work, pay has become competitive, and promotions for those who put 100% in their work, clients and the companies vision and mission statement.
cons: Metrocare may not be a good fit for those who are not wholeheartedly supporting mental health clients who are striving for recovery.

review_title: The staff at Metrocare are dedicated and passionate about our work in the community
pros: Although I am in administration, there is not a day that goes by that I am not touched and moved at how committed our team is. We have made great strides in so many areas weathering through Covid. And, we have big plans for the future of our services. It is hard work, but it is fun and challenging to be involved with such exciting growth on the horizon.
cons: The reality is that when you are in healthcare and you receive government funding, there is a lot of paperwork. We are required to have an electronic health system and there is not one out there that is perfect. It's just the reality in the time of HIPAA. And patient privacy is paramount so just know that's part of the gig. Also, funders require that all orgs meet performance metrics. It's a tough challenge but it ensure that our clients get the quality they deserve.

pros: good benefit, flexible hours, good coworkers
cons: pay is rather low, jobs that are not included in your job description

job_title: Licensed Practitioner of Healing Arts (LPHA) in Dallas, TX
pros: My manager makes sure we have our days off when requested.
cons: It can be stressful when a client is in crisis.

pros: more independence on the job and less micromanaging, and I am in a much calmer and more organized department than some of the others in the organization.
cons: Time management is not just it, you have to be able to be distracted by multiple things at any given moment and be able to ump back to where you were. You have to love busywork type paperwork (excessive and not always logical) but that is HHS for you. You are typically helping the organization and only sometimes actually helping people directly, so if that is a factor in your job satisfaction it isn't a great position. You will regularly get company-wide emails from higher ups thanking clinicians and doctors and people you never see for all their hard work but service coordinators are NEVER thanked for their stress levels and efforts.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Dallas, TX
pros: Then only I see working here is that you have weekends off.
cons: Horrible place to refer anyone to receive mental health services. Providers are over worked and employee the turnover rate is high.

pros: You have a chance to provide meaningful work. Good experience if you can handle all the cons.
cons: Many people complain about the expectations being too much, however, the main problem is the lack of support from management and no effort to boost morale. No team spirit, employees are suspicious of each other and this is encourage by the attitudes of the managers. Fraud is encouraged to make numbers, unethical behavior is overlooked and downplayed as nothing, and the employees fear to say anything because management is biased and will retaliate even if you report anonymously. Even if you are the very best at your job you are not safe of management does not like you.

job_title: Customer Service Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: Opportunity for growth within the company
cons: Fast paced and implement additional policies without advanced notice.

pros: Free generic meds at pharmacy to employees.
cons:
The negative reviews you see here are all true. Any positive reviews were probably written by someone in administration. 
If you think you are coming here to help people in need you are not. Your job is only to make contact, write a note in the crappy electronic system then move on. You are discouraged from spending too much time with clients. . A certain percentage of your time must be billable and your numbers are given to you each week and you are held accountable for them or lose your job. Who goes into Human Services to be treated like that? On the MH side meds and counseling are provided but still it's "make contact and move on". Intellectual Disability side is the same only worse. THE JOB IS TELEMARKETING AT BEST. 
Working in the field has unreasonable expectations attached known as benchmarks. Your job is only to make your benchmark by any means necessary, which could mean nights and weekends. Fraud is rampant.
Management uses threats and intimidation to get what they think they want. Your job is always being held over your head if you don't make your numbers. There are no professional managers here. All of them are past clinicians, psychologists, social workers, doctors, etc with no training in management. Their only skills are parenting and whatever they learned from their last supervisor. 
CEO is worried about turnover but does not know how to do anything about it. No recognition, no incentives or reward system. No culture and nothing to work for except a below average salary. You can be assigned tasks that are not in your job description. You can be moved around at will into anything they want you to do like it or not. If you don't like it you are told you can leave. They do not want to help employees find positions that will be mutually beneficial.
Front line workers are treated like low class people. Input from workers is unwelcome as managers and executives are too immature to accept that someone else may have a good idea. Managers are unwilling to learn new things, be creative or adapt. Managers are intimidated by good workers and don't want to be shown up. 
Favoritism (and other "isms") are rampant. People are hired based on anything except qualifications. Intelligence is not appreciated here. Just quietly do your job, your ideas are not welcome because, again, managers are too immature to consider they may need to grow.
The quality of your work does not matter. If all of your clients call in to support you, you will never be told or recognized even if you make your numbers. Benchmark is all that matters. 
There is also very limited upward mobility. Managers rarely leave and when they do they will groom their favorite or execs will look outside to fill the position.
Leaders here are basically bullies. And many managers here are dinosaurs. Not because of age, but because of mentality.

job_title: Business Office Support II in Dallas, TX
pros: Metrocare requires a lot for the little pay.
cons: I have been working for Metrocare for a while, the best thing is just having a job during the pandemic.

pros: Managers are great... Teamwork is big

pros: flexibility with schedule... you can make your own work schedule.
cons: don't work here...you'll never move up in the company and the work isn't worth the pay.

pros: Location , staff, distance, boss volume
cons: Volume helpful professional, fun quit

review_title: If you want to gain great experience this is the place.
pros:
I can't think of a better company to gain as much mental health and social work experience.

LPC Intern heaven (clinical hours are abundant here in QMHP role)

Flexible Schedule 

Offers free clinical supervision
cons:
You work in the field. If someone hurt or killed you no one would know until your progress notes we're not completed within 24 hours deadline.

If a client harmful to you there is no consequences for the client. You can't tell them you couldn't be allowed back, you are told by management to leave, but they required to return for the next scheduled visit. Thereby reinforcing the behavior. 

Be prepared to work evenings you are on the clients schedule not the companies 8 to 5 schedule. 

Low compensation for the work you do with families. Requirements and expectations increase often, but not compensation for it. 

Numbers based company 100%. Nothing else matters.

job_title: QUALIFIED MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONAL in Dallas, TX
pros: Other good/caring professionals/staff attempting to make positive difference, the potential to make a difference in the lives of others, some flexibility in setting your daily schedule, lots of training in the beginning, stipend for additional education/language proficiency/mileage, the professional experience is beneficial. If you make it here you will make it anywhere, even if you've only been here for a couple of months.
cons: High stress(i.e. meeting productions standards w/ current client population is difficult), low pay for the amount of work (but they pay more than others if you're not fully licensed), you're always working in an attempt to meet production standards. Population is difficult to work with, requiring lots of energy to educate/redirect; safety can be a concern (i.e. physical/health-wise/emotionally). Job is emotionally draining w/ high need population.  High turnover rate for QMHP--possibly 50% or more. Even when doing your best if you do not meet your productivity you will get written up. Medical insurance benefits are awful--- you are paying a lot out of pocket/high deductible. This job should never be considered a long term prospect; its for training only.

review_title: If you're looking for IT work, keep looking.
pros: If you don't care and don't do your job you will excel here! Just lay low and nobody will notice how incompetent you actually are! Plus they give regular computer janitors outrageous titles like "Support Engineer", looks great on your resume for when you inevitably leave here, I guess.
cons: If you do care and do perform your job, you will be held accountable even though the people not doing their job make your's impossible. All of the technology implementations are poorly executed so nothing ever works correctly and every move by the IT  management just creates more issues that support has to deal with. And when you point out things aren't working correctly the IT director will blame YOU, lowly computer janitor, for not pointing it out sooner. They provide ZERO training for supporting the medical records software that everyone uses on a daily basis. Legacy staff are totally unhelpful and super clique-y. Despite being an ostensibly progressive organization I met the most bigoted people I have ever come across in my entire life in the IT department of this company. The entire experience was just a beating.

pros:
- You will make connections with people here that you will carry with you into the future. 
- Upper management has an open-door policy and will at least appear to listen to your concerns
- Beautiful retirement package (if you make it long enough to build it up).
- Always challenging environment
cons:
- Internal processes are not well documented. 
- Severe lack of training on the bread-and-butter programs that the org runs on. 
- Poor communication within IT sub departments
- Unrealistic performance expectations
- Hard work and sheer dedication goes unnoticed
- HR (People Dept.) is UNAPPROACHABLE and poorly trained (in my opinion)
- Lack of appreciation of what IT does within other departments.
- Inconsistency of reporting
- Laugh-worthy infrastructure
- Terrible Security Auditing
- Timidness or a "sugar-coated" mentality when addressing employee performace
- Lack of upper management auditing
- Potential corruption within higher-salaried individuals
- Oh, and my favorite, Three letter officers blaming the lowest tier of support for things so beyond their control it's laughable. 
- The list goes on...

pros: They will hire anyone. However, there are better positions to work out of school just be patient and do your research.
cons: Do not work here. Very unprofessional staff the mileage reimbursement is not worth the wear and tear that is put on your car.  There is an unrealistic benchmark that initially is stated to not be something to worry about until you are put on probation for meeting a benchmark of seeing clients, depending on which department you get. Certain department are constantly losing funding for their program which means there is even more pressure on you to meet the benchmark because of previous employees not seeing clients which would now be a responsibility of yours to save their program. you would be walking in to a deficit. If you try to quit on them which you have a right to they attempt to retaliate against you or gossip about you to other staff.  There is limited ability to  move upward.

pros: Flexible Schedule that allows you to work your own schedule. Good benefits and decent pay for those new to the field.
cons: Incredibly high standards to try and achieve. Bottom line is focused on quantity of care, not quality. QMHP's and LPC's are overworked and given too short a time period to work on casenotes. AVATAR system creates work difficulties that then get blamed on employees, despite only have a 3 hour training that occurred three weeks before it was rolled out. The caseloads were also ridiculous, with LPC's having over 200 people on their caseload and being unable to achieve proper level of care for clients due to being wildly overbooked. QMHP's struggled with upkeeping on clients who are non-compliant.

pros: You will get very good experience working at Metrocare Services. If you can work here, you can work anywhere. Flexible scheduling is a plus. I also enjoyed my co-workers that I worked with. I also really loved the clients that I got to serve. Metrocare would be a great place to work if it had better management and a less stressful benchmark.
cons: All the upper management cares about is making your benchmark. They don't care about quality, they only care about quantity. There were people who worked there that did a horrible job with the clients, but because they made bench they were able to keep their jobs. The job was extremely stressful and they offered low wages.

pros: experience working with mental health clients
cons: the job descriptions are misleading & their weekly bench is ridiculous & you would have to engage in fraud in order to achieve bench weekly. Bench is $3,024 a week if you do not make bench you will get written up and eventually terminated. If you make bench 6 weeks in a row and do not make bench the 7th week you will be written up for that missed week & after 3 write ups you are terminated. They want all QMHP's to be in the field conducting homevisits 90% of the time. They do not care about your safety & only question what billing code did you use and for how long to ensure the most amount of money & not the quality of service.

pros:
Working to get hours for licenses and building your resume is easy  with this company. 
You will help those that don't have access to the best care so you feel you are really helping. 
You can move around in the company pretty easily if you make connections with managers in other departments.
cons:
If you do not like working to meet numbers this is not the position for you (QMHP).
It's easy to just do what's needed and not go above and beyond because it's about numbers.
Disconnect between those in the admin office and those on the front line

pros: Serving people with intellectual disabilities is a very rewarding opportunity.  Metrocare Services affords us the chance to positively impact the lives of families trying to love and care for their love ones.
cons: Leadership...leadership...leadership!  When you have leaders with antiquated views and leadership styles needs to be replaced.  Unfortunately talented people are overlooked and eventually leave without being tapped into.  Its sad, but I am sure I will be transitioning soon due to the poor organizational leadership.

pros:
-  3 floating holiday that you can use right away if you are hired between Jan - Apr which is very nice.
-  Nice 403b package with matching
-  So far, awesome people to work with
-  Salary is good
-  Your hard works are not going unnoticed
-  Company pays your life insurance which is 2xannual salary.  I  haven't seen that for quite a long time.
-  Training is provided
cons:
- Work can be hectic some time
- High turn-over rate which affects moral in the company
- People feel comfortable with where they are and don't want to push themselves harder for improvement.
- Lack of communication between teams

pros: The flexibility is awesome! You basically create your own schedule as long as it is accommodating to the families you are working with. There is potential to make bonuses as long as you are meeting your bench.
cons: This organization only cares about you meeting your benchmark. So, you're not really providing quality services because every client becomes a dollar amount. It's very hard to focus on helping when in the back of your mind you know that your job is on the line if you don't meet your bench. This organization is really bad about requesting things to be completed and turned in at the last minute.

pros: Food served at very awkward meetings.
cons: These are my opinions: no culpability for their actions, their People Department doesn’t have your best interests at heart and if you try to report misconduct, they will turn you into the perpetrator. Very bizarre structuring. I should have known something was wrong when I went to their new hire orientation and the instructor, a very nice older gentleman, was completely disrespected by very ghetto- acting employees. This would never happen if you worked for another county facility in the Dallas area. They also originally gave me an annual salary when they hired me and at the new hire orientation gave us a piece of paper with our hourly wage written on the paper, and my hourly wage was incorrect. I had to correct it and turn it back in. They give you outdated technology to use. If you wor

review_title: Horrible. They work you crazy. They dont know how to treat worker Its always bench bench mark or you are out of there.
pros: There is not any. If you like working  with mentally  ill clients this is the job for you.
cons: You  have  a metrics  to meet. No organization. Very low low pay. They run you like a dog. Lots  of audits, overwork  you for low pay. high  case  load. Run your car down to nothing.  Job very stressful.  Always about the dollar.

job_title: Call Center Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Actually helping people in need with their daily issues. Really laid back job, but very strict rules with protected health information.
cons: Callers usually on the rude side.  Repetitive work day to day with very little spontaneity...excitement from job comes in the form of a crisis call.  HIGH STRESS JOB.

review_title: Stay away if you value yourself
pros: “Flexible work schedule” the people you serve are nice and really  appreciate you. Coworkers for the most part are cool
cons: UPPER MANAGEMENT DOES NOT CARE ABOUT YOU AT ALL. YOU ARE NOTHING MORE THAN A NUMBER.  All the company cares about isnits numbers the  benchmarks you have to meet are IMPOSSIBLE. You will drive yourself crazy trying to have a life with this job. If you are not making 100 % prepare to be have weekly meetings being talked to like a child. PLEASE READ ALL THE REVIEWS. WE ARE TRYING TO SAVE YOU THE STRESS.  And the benefits SUCK!!!! Your paying out of pocket for everything pretty much.

job_title: LIDDA Service Coordinator GR in Dallas, TX
pros: I love the job when I am able to "do the job". I absolutely love my coworkers and the relaxed office atmosphere. I am not micromanaged and have a lot of flexibility on my scheduling. I have a nice balance between being out in the field and being at a desk. I really enjoy my families. The LIDDA employees care about the quality of their work.  The pay is great for human services. Applicants need to understand that if you want to climb the cooperate ladder, get rich, and get commissions and all that jazz, stay out of human services. Metrocare also has great benefits available.
cons: The training is pathetic. Yes, you get good information, but in bits and pieces in no logical order. The training classes often teach you a different way to do procedures than what is actually done, and is primarily about navigating Avatar and not what do to and when. It isn't right that I received 50 cases after a month and a half in the field when I am in training the first 90 days after the first 2-4 weeks of the non existent "academy".  The LIDDA employees DO care about care quality but Metrocare overall only cares about benchmarks.  The expected numbers are not unreasonable at all, it can be done, but I am expected to handle all these cases with bare-minimum competency, which does not work well for me. It was emphasized in orientation that we were to do things efficiently the first time since it was a waste of time and money to have to go back and repeat a task over and over again to get it right, but if they don't change training "techniques" it will continue to be incredibly inefficient and just about making numbers regardless of ineffectiveness. Basically the "fast food" of human services.

review_title: Comprehensive mental health services and experience
pros: The clinical team I work with is the best. I have grown through working here. We make an impact in the community.
cons: The learning curve is steep but the team is in place to provide support. There are plenty of training opportunities.

review_title: Poorly construction organization, from the bottom up.
pros: Position gives much experience with mental disorders, and community issues such as poverty and homelessness.  The position offered the opportunity to receive contact clinical hours for certification from the state.  On some days, better than being broke and unemployed.
cons: Severe lack of training for new and existing employees.  Upper management has no real knowledge of what underlings do, and are completely out of touch with employees and clients.  Overworked and burned out staff, not enough incentive to keep going.  Poor retention of staff after receiving hours for certification.  Low morale and even lower pay scale.  Must constantly watch your back, since management will get rid of you for low productivity rates, even when it isn't your fault, such as when clients don't come for their appointments.  Coworkers feel pressure to falsely report their numbers, and so much fraud is committed, and goes unchecked.  Work and life balance?!? That was non-existent there.  Atmosphere at many clinics was ripe for a major uprising from clients, as the process was slow to get in for an appointment, and waiting was even worse, as all types of people were left wandering around, and no one ever knew what someone was capable of doing.

review_title: This place is the bottom rung
pros: You're joking, right? No pros.
cons:
An absolutely awful place to work. I wanted to like it but anyone with any self-respect at all will move on. Save yourself the heartache and take your talent somewhere you’ll be appreciated.

It’s not difficult to pinpoint the main problem for me - this is an organization that lacks self-awareness. It may be because of its size. But in my experience, the people that they hire for management roles are miserable retreads who are made worse because they are overwhelmed and confused. There is no plan. Or if there is, nobody knows about it. Like zombies, the management feeds off of the chaos. Their leader is shady. I’ve heard talks of fraud but I don’t know. HR is obviously contrived. The clinic is a mess and I know there are people on staff who shouldn’t be practicing.

I saw no real talent or anyone who is inspired by their job. Again, I imagine it’s because anyone who wants to feel valued doesn’t stick around. This place does a good job of quickly breaking your spirit. You’ll leave feeling used up.

You’ll also learn about this club of employees who have been at this place for a long time. It’s a joke. If you meet these people, you’ll see that their old and stodgy, so dug in that they can only press the repeat button. This place champions them because they think their tenure means something. Believe me, it doesn’t. They’re just the poster children for the other unmotivated employees you’ll find on staff.

It’s really a shame because I wanted to be a part of something special. But you won’t find it here. They’re bullies. They mistreat their employees and on the inside, you’ll see that they don’t care at all about those who come to them for help.

You’ll be greatly unimpressed.

pros: Clinical experience with mental health clients and developmentally challenged clients across all age groups.
cons: Mileage on your vehicle if you are a field based worker, management turnover, little work resources, and little on the job training.

pros:
1. They're always hiring. Which is telling.
2. Never having to go back
cons:
I was a QMHP at the Metrocare clinic at The Bridge homeless shelter. I don’t have anything positive to say about this workplace. It was a nightmare. Ran like a prison.
The team morale at this location in particular was so bleak. I came in highly motivated and ready to work hard for the clients, but my spirits were just beaten down by the apathetic attitudes of leadership. There were so many times I tried to engage and was ignored that I eventually just gave up. People keep to themselves, do the bare minimum, and spend a lot of time on their phones...
One of the psychiatrists even said to me, "You need to get a better job. You can do better than this. They don't care about you and they know you won't stick around, nobody does." !!!!!
I've worked in other mental healthcare roles before and never have I witnessed this unwillingness from coworkers to actually provide care and be engaged. I'm used to being around smart, driven, compassionate clinicians who fight for their patients. I didn't see that here. I got side eye and avoidance for bringing up ideas and making suggestions. I would try to engage with people and build rapport but I was met with apathy or subtle hostility.
I repeatedly raised concerns to HR and other higher ups not a single one of them have had the professionalism to respond and communicate fairly. It's a disorganized and chaotic organization that needs revamping.

pros:
Field-based position allows for avoidance of office drama. 
Personal satisfaction in empowering others to increase their quality of life.
cons:
Deputy CEO is a tyrant who intimidates her managers by yelling and threatening. 
No over-time pay, yet the job requires working more than 40 hours. 
Unreasonable quotas, referred to as bench marks. 
Often heard management quotes: "I was interviewing when you came, and I'll be interviewing when you go." "I need a service coordinator, not a specific service coordinator."

pros: Helping others, good pay, learning experience, chances to move up in the company. Work independently, you flex your own schedule. Staff is friendly.
cons: Working overtime because too many people are on your caseload and too much work to do for one person. IT department sucks. Constantly changing protocols.

pros: Good Health Benefits and you didnt have to work weekends or holidays
cons: If you didnt meet benchmark you were let go. Training was long but not effective.  Upper Management did not help much and  the department was unorganized

pros: Employees can get most of their meds filled for free or cheap at the pharmacy.
cons:
-Toxic culture
-Benchmarks are very difficult to meet.   
-Marginally competent managers
 -Managers are their own cliques and 
   have a "group think" mentality.
-Little regard for the mental health of 
  their employees.
-Lead by intimidation
I could go on and on...

I think Dr Burgess means well, but doesn't see everything going on.
